title-group.article-title: Genotoxicity of heavy metals to the larvae of Chironomus kiiensis Tokunaga after short-term exposure

article-meta.aff: 1School of Biological Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia (USM), Penang, Malaysia
2Centre for Marine and Coastal Studies, Universiti Sains Malaysia (USM), Penang, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: Salman A Al-Shami, School of Biological Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia (USM), Penang 11800, Malaysia Email: alshami200@gmail.com

abstract.p: The genotoxic effects of increasing concentrations (below lethal concentration [LC50]) of cadmium ([Cd] 0.1, 1 and 10 mg/L), copper ([Cu] 0.2, 2 and 20 mg/L) and zinc ([Zn] 0.5, 5 and 50 mg/L) on Chironomus kiiensis were evaluated using alkaline comet assay after exposure for 24 h. Both the tail moment and the olive tail moment showed significant differences between the control and different concentrations of Cd, Cu and Zn (Kruskal–Wallis, p < 0.05). The highest concentration of Cd was associated with higher DNA damage to C. kiiensis larvae compared with Cu and Zn. The potential genotoxicity of these metals to C. kiiensis was Cd > Cu > Zn.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The pollution of aquatic ecosystems has emerged as a major ecological problem globally coinciding with rapid industrialization and urbanization (Perez et al., 2010). In Malaysia, numerous rivers have been classified as very polluted and shown to be contaminated with pesticides, organic wastes and heavy metals (DOE, 1994). For instance, Juru River is one the most polluted rivers in Malaysia, with sediments highly contaminated with heavy metals such as cadmium (Cd), copper (Cu) and zinc (Zn) (Al-Shami et al., 2010a,b, 2011). These contaminants are most likely the discharges from the light and heavy industries in the Prai Industrial Estate (established in the early 1970s), Penang, Malaysia (Al-Shami et al., 2010b).

The larvae of nonbiting aquatic midges (Chironomidae: Diptera) are ubiquitously distributed, sensitive to many pollutants, relatively easy to culture and have a short life cycle. These criteria make them suitable organisms for ecotoxicological monitoring (Al-Shami et al., 2010b; Park and Choi, 2009; Shuhaimi-Othman et al., 2011). Chironomus kiiensis is the dominant species of the genus Chironomus in South East Asian countries including Malaysia, inhabiting rivers, wetlands and rice agroecosystems (Al-Shami et al., 2010a, 2010b). This species had been previously shown to be a suitable organism for bioassesment and environmental monitoring (Al-Shami et al., 2006).

The biological effect of heavy metal exposure is of growing concern due to the increasing release of such metals into the environment via industrial and agricultural processes, exacerbated by their tendency to accumulate in biotic systems (Whiteside et al., 2010). Due to the increasing input of chemical contaminants into the aquatic environment, it has become necessary to develop sensitive and reliable methods to assess the impact of such toxicants on aquatic organisms at an early exposure stage (Mitchelmore et al., 1998). The contamination of heavy metals can cause community alteration and morphological deformities to chironomids larvae (Al-Shami et al., 2010a,b; Marziali et al., 2010). Meanwhile, exposures of aquatic species to genotoxic substances and processes can produce chemical or physical modifications to DNA, commonly measured as DNA adducts or DNA strand breaks, which are sensitive markers of genotoxic damage (Jha, 2008; Lee and Steinert, 2003). The comet assay, also called the single-cell gel electrophoresis (SCGE) primarily measures DNA strand breakage in single cells and has been widely applied to investigate the effect of various organic pollutants on chironomid larvae (Park and Choi, 2009) and fish (Simoniello et al., 2009).

Application of living organisms, specifically chironomids, in biomonitoring of the aquatic ecosystems is not commonly practiced in Malaysia. In this study, chemical-induced DNA damages were investigated by measuring DNA strand breaks in C. kiiensis, a dominant chironomid species in Malaysian rivers, after short-term exposure (24 h) to sublethal concentrations of zinc (Zn), copper (Cu) and cadmium (Cd) in order to determine the genotoxic biomarkers for risk assessment.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Chironomus kiiensis larvae were collected from the Juru River Basin between November 2009 and January 2010 and maintained in the Aquatic Entomology Laboratory (School of Biological Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia [USM]) at 27 ± 2°C and 13:11 h (light: dark). The larvae were routinely reared in aquarium containers (30 × 20 × 15 cm3). Chironomid larvae are associated with soft substrata, where they can build tubes and cases. In this experiment, sand sediments and tissue paper were provided as substrates. The tissue paper was cut into thin, short strips (3 × 15 mm2), sterilized in ethanol for 24 h and air-dried for at least 3 days before use. Approximately, four to six strips were used (Al-Shami et al., 2006). The larvae were supplied with fish food (Sanyuichiban, A&P Aquarium System Sdn. Bhd., Malaysia) every 2 days following the standard method of Ali and Lord (1980). Pure culture of C. kiiensis larvae was used as experimental animals.

Fourth-instar midge larvae removed with a dropper were placed into 30 × 40 cm2 white plastic trays filled with dechlorinated tap water (filtered by activated carbon filtration system) and allowed to acclimate for 10 to 12 h in the trays prior to use in the test following the method of Ali et al. (2009).

Ten fourth-instar larvae were transferred into each of 33 plastic container (12 cm height, 8 cm diameter at the top and 4 cm at the bottom) containing 100 ml of the corresponding heavy metal concentration. A total number of 330 larvae were used in this study. No food was supplied to the larvae during the 24-h exposure test. The selected concentrations of Zn (0.5, 5 and 50 mg/L), Cu (0.2, 2 and 20 mg/L) and Cd (0.1, 1 and 10 mg/L) were prepared using standard solutions and were below the lethal concentration [LC50] level for C. kiiensis, according to the study of Ebau (2010). For comparison, Shuhaimi-Othman et al. (2011) reported that the LC50 of Zn, Cu and Cd to Chironomus javanus under similar conditions were 14.40, 1.96 and 0.19 mg/L, respectively. However, higher LC50 of 70.60, 95.21 and 23.53 mg/L for Zn, Cu and Cd, respectively, were reported in the bioassessment of heavy metals to C. kiiensis (Ebau, 2010).

The exposure experiment was conducted at room temperature of 27 ± 2°C and photoperiod of 13:11 h (light: dark) for 24 h. Dechlorinated tap water was used as negative control, while hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) at a concentration of 20 mM was used as positive control. Each treatment was conducted in triplicate.

A total of 10 larvae were collected from each treatment, negative and positive control containers, and were homogenized in 1 ml ice-cold 1× PBS containing 20 mM EDTA and 10 mM dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (Park and Choi 2009). The homogenate was recovered by centrifugation (13 rpm for 3 min). The supernatant was transferred to a clean and sterilized microtube and immediately mixed with low melting agarose (LMA) provided by Trevigen Inc. (USA) in a ratio of 1:10 (cell suspension: LMA). An alkaline comet assay (Singh et al. 1988) was performed using CometAssay kit (Trevigen Inc., USA) following the manufacturer procedures. Alkaline electrophoresis (pH > 13) was applied to the slides at 300 mA and 30 V for 25 min and at 4°C. The slides were neutralized in water followed by 70% ethanol. The slides were then dried at <45°C for 15 min.

The prepared slides were stained with 100 µL of SYBER Green I. They were then observed under ×400 magnification using a fluorescence microscope (Olympus BH-2, Japan) equipped with camera (ProgRes Cloplus, Laser optic Systeme, Germany) and 1B excitation filter of 495 nm and barrier filter of 515 nm. Approximately 75 cells from each treatment were examined. The DNA damage was expressed as the tail moment (=tail length × tail %DNA/100), olive tail moment ([tail mean − head mean] × tail %DNA) and percentage of DNA in the comet tail using TriTek CometScore (Version 1.5, TriTek Corp., USA). Data were examined for normality in their distribution (Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, p < 0.05). Statistical differences between the control and treated larvae were examined using Kruskal–Wallis test (SPPS, Version 13).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: No chironomid mortality was observed during the 24-h exposure period in all treatments. The viability of the isolated cells was always more than 90% for all treatments. All the DNA damage parameter data did not show normal distribution (Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, p < 0.05). Therefore, nonparametric statistical test of Kruskal–Wallis was employed at p < 0.05. The percentage of DNA in the tail, tail moment and olive tail moment was shown to be significantly different among the metal and control treatments (Kruskal–Wallis, p < 0.01, χ2 = 126.105, 108.194 and 104.32, respectively). All investigated metals induced significant amount of DNA damage in C. kiiensis larvae after a short exposure of 24 h. The genotoxicity of Cd was the highest followed by Cu and Zn (Figure 1). All three studied metals revealed genotoxic potential at sublethal levels (Table 1). Tail moment increased significantly at all three Zn concentrations (0.5, 5 and 50 mg/L) with values of 1.06, 3.31 and 4.4 µm, respectively. Similarly, the olive tail moment values elevated significantly with increasing concentrations (1.87, 3.25 and 3.6 µm, respectively). DNA strand breaks in the larvae exposed to Cu at concentrations of 0.2, 2 and 20 mg/L was higher compared with Zn. At the lowest concentration of 0.2 mg/L, the strand breaks expressed as tail moment and olive tail moment values were 1.33 and 2.19 µm, respectively. For the highest concentration of Cu, the tail moment and olive tail moment values were 4.16 and 3.44 µm, respectively. At the lowest concentration of Cd of 0.1 mg/L, high DNA strand breaks were reported (3.72 and 3.25 µm, respectively). However, at a concentration of 1 mg/L, the DNA damage was lower when compared with the 0.1 mg/L with tail moment and olive tail moment values of 2.48 and 2.9 µm, respectively. The highest adverse effect on the DNA, among the three studied metals, was reported at 10 mg/L of Cd with tail moment and olive moment values of 7.24 and 5.88 µm, respectively.

sec.p: Contamination with heavy metals in the Malaysian aquatic ecosystems is evident (Al-Shami et al., 2010a, 2010b , 2011). It is well established that heavy metals have adverse effect on distribution and diversity of macroinvertebrate and chironomid communities (Marziali et al., 2010). Moreover, heavy metal contamination is reported to be a major cause of deformities in the chironomid larvae (Al-Shami et al., 2010b). Heavy metals and other genotoxic compounds represent a major environmental challenge, because they may lead to impaired reproduction, accelerated aging processes and tumor induction in exposed individuals (Haldsrud and Krokje, 2009). Consequently, it is essential to develop methods that predict genotoxic impact of exposure to environmental contaminants before serious effects on the ecosystem can occur (Haldsrud and Krokje, 2009). The DNA strand breaks resulting from a variety of genotoxic agents have been investigated in many aquatic animals using the comet assay and shown to be a reliable and sensitive biomarker (Lee and Steinert, 2003; Park and Choi, 2009).

In the present study, the selected metals (Zn, Cu and Cd) showed different genotoxic effect on C. kiiensis larvae. The highest DNA damage (DNA tail percentage of 41.88%) corresponded to 10 mg/L of Cd exposure. Cd is classified as a group I human carcinogen and is also carcinogenic to experimental and wildlife animals (IARC, 1987). The mechanism of Cd toxicity to animal and plant cells is complicated (Haldsrud and Krokje, 2009). It has the ability to inhibit antioxidant enzymes such as catalase, glutathione peroxidase (GPox) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) involved in the removal of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Valko et al., 2005). Mechanisms underlying Cd-induced ROS formation involve disturbance of mitochondrial electron transfer chains and damage to lysosomal membranes (Fotakis et al., 2005; Wang et al., 2004). Cd also has the ability to interfere with DNA repair mechanisms such as nucleotide excision repair (Hartwig, 1998).

At lower concentrations, toxicity of Zn to C. kiiensis larval cells was lower when compared to the other two tested metals Cu and Cd. Lee et al. (2006) reported that Cd has a cytotoxicity effect on C. tentans larvae increasing the gene expression of heat shock proteins (Hsp) at concentrations of 0.2, 2 and 20 mg/L. Cd was also reported to cause DNA damage in earthworms at a concentration of 20 mg/L with the tail DNA percentage of 34.08% (Fourie et al., 2007). By comparison, the possibility of occurrence of DNA damage after exposure to Cd in C. kiiensis (highest tail DNA percentage of 41.88% at 10 mg/L) larvae was higher when compared with earthworm. The undulating movement behavior of C. kiiensis larvae probably made them more susceptible to toxicants.

Our study revealed that the DNA damage caused by Cd was quicker and more effective compared to Cu—only 29.06% DNA in the comet tail—but at a twofold concentration of 20 mg/L. Karouna-Renier and Zehr (2003) reported that a concentration of Cu below 2 mg/L caused significant effects on C. tentans larvae at the molecular level by inducing the expression of certain protein genes. Cu has the ability to participate in redox cycling, ultimately leading to the formation of ROS such as hydroxyl radicals ( · OH) (Valko et al., 2005). Cu also has the ability to bind directly to DNA (Moriwaki et al., 2008; Sagripanti et al., 1991). In addition, contamination with Zn has also been reported to cause DNA damage in various insects such as grasshopper (Augustyniak et al., 2006).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The concentrations of Zn, Cu and Cd below LC50 were proven to have a genotoxic effect on C. kiiensis larvae. The potential of these metals to cause DNA damage to C. kiiensis larval cells is Cd > Cu > Zn, after short-term exposure (24 h). The comet assay or SCGE has been proved to be a reliable and effective biomarker tool to assess the genotoxicity of different organic and inorganic pollutants. Further assessments of DNA damage caused by other pollutant, field-collected sediments and waters are needed.
